What is a NICHO (Shrine)?

When the Conquistadors came to the Americas, they brought with them many of the traditions of Spain, specially those having to do with religion. It was customary in Colonial homes to have a niche in the wall, or a "nicho" featuring the image of a saint, which would bless the house. These could be carved into a wall, or could be made of tin and hung on a wall. So, a nicho is essentially a recessed frame which holds either a figure or an image of a particular saint. Today in Mexico, nichos and altars to saints, (especially to the Virgin of Guadalupe, who is the patron saint of Mexico) are present in homes and in businesses, often dressed up with flower and candle offerings.

name: Clay skulls with milagros
description:
Skulls Size: 6.5" x 5" x 6.5"

Dia de los Muertos skulls is hand painted by one of our artists Mexico. The skull features humorous Day of the Dead art. 

Due to the size and the type of packaging the price of shipping will be a little bit more expensive. 

(All shrines will be send via recorded delivery worldwide.)

Milagros are small religious charms that people usually nail onto sacred objects,
pin on the clothing of saint statues, or hang with little red ribbons or threads from altars and shrines.
The word "milagro" means "miracle".
Typically, a believer will make a vow to a saint or to a sacred object, and later on she will make a pilgrimage to the site of the shrine or church and take a milagro there and leave it as a sign of gratitude and devotion. People also carry milagros for protection and good luck. Different milagros have different meanings and uses, and are often interpreted differently by different people, or for different occasions. For example, a milagro of a body part, such as a leg, might be used as part of a prayer or vow for the improvement for some condition associated with a leg - such as arthritis. Or, it might refer to a concept such a travel, the leg implying walking, which implies any form of travel. Similarly,
a heart might represent a heart condition that one is praying for a cure: or a romance, or the Sacred Heart of Jesus or of Mary, and a prayer that the power of those spiritual forces
might come into ones life. Often, a retablo or some other sacred image in a home will have milagros nailed to the frame, in such a way that the saint represented in the picture might bless the persons represented by the milagros, or the cares of these persons.

name: MEXICAN BINGO. DISCOVERING, PLAYING, ENJOYING MEXICO.
description:
FUN FOR EVERYONE MEXICAN BINGO by Cesar Vulcano+,(Collectors edition)

Includes 10 playing boards, 64 colorful playing cards and a booklet giving a brief documentation of each card (in English). Available ONLY at House of Guadalupe 


DISCOVERING, PLAYING, ENJOYING MEXICO.
The Loteria game, often called Mexican Bingo, has been a popular board game in Mexico for over 200 years. This is a fun game for all ages and can be a great learning tool for young people learning Spanish.
One of the most influential Mexican designs, has been Clemente Jacques playing cards, first published in the 1920‚Äôs and still produced today by Pasatiempos Gallo S.A. de C.V. This original set includes 10 playing boards and 54 playing cards. To use the game as intended, cards are called loud one by one, and if a player has the picture on their board the space is marked with a chip or a small bean.
Cesar Vulcano+ (House of Guadalupe) has re-designed this New Mexican Bingo exclusively for the U.K. Includes 10 playing boards, 64 colorful playing cards and a booklet giving a brief documentation of each card (in English).
This is my small homage to all Mexican people and to Their country, I tried to put together all the things that got my attention during all these years traveling to Mexico, I hope you enjoy playing this game , as much as I enjoyed designing it.

name: Day of the Dead board games
description:
Day of the Dead Mexican bingo includes 54 cards and 10 tables to play.
Snap Day of the Dead game includes 30 pairs of cards (60 in total)


Mexican Bingo It is one of the most popular and of more tradition games in Mexico. At all Mexican fairs, one of the greatest attractions, are the lottery stands. Where over twenty people get to play every game.
Though, it can be play by three persons: one calls the lottery, and the other two can place a chip or a bean over their board game, as figures on cards are shown and call.
Lottery cards are 54 and coincide with the figures on the game board. For an easier identification, game boards and cards have figures with names and numbers.
Among the most usual variations, we have:

FULL GAME BOARD, HORIZONTAL LINE, VERTICAL LINE,

DIAGONAL LINE, LETTER SHAPES.

The first one to fill the game board or the agreed line‚Ä¶WINS, CRYING: LOTTERY!!
KEEP THIS BEAUTIFUL TRADITION!

name: SANTA MUERTE
description:
Made of resin.
30 cm H

Santa Muerte is a sacred figure venerated in Mexico, probably a syncretism between Mesoamerican and Catholic beliefs. The name literally translates to "Holy Death" or "Saint Death." Mexican culture since the pre-Columbian era has maintained a certain reverence towards death, which can be seen in the widespread Mexican celebration of the syncretic Day of the Dead. Catholic elements of that celebration include the use of skeletons to remind people of their mortality.

name: Flags
description:
Our Lady of Guadalupe flag
Made of cotton. Dimensions: 91.5cm H by 60cm W

Our Lady of San Juan de los Lagos flag, 
Made of cotton. Dimensions: 80cm H by 60cm H

For more than three hundred years, the Virgin Mary of Guadalupe has been celebrated and revered in Mexico as the Patroness of Mexican and Indian peoples, and as the Queen of the Americas.
She stands on home altars, lends her name to men and women alike, and finds herself at rest under their skin in tattoos. Guadalupe‚Äôs image proliferates on candles, decals, tiles, murals, and old and new sacred art. Churches and religious orders carry her name, as do place names and streets. Far from vulgarizing her image, these items personalize her and maintain her presence in daily life.

What is a NICHO (Shrine)?

When the Conquistadors came to the Americas, they brought with them many of the traditions of Spain, specially those having to do with religion. It was customary in Colonial homes to have a niche in the wall, or a "nicho" featuring the image of a saint, which would bless the house. These could be carved into a wall, or could be made of tin and hung on a wall. So, a nicho is essentially a recessed frame which holds either a figure or an image of a particular saint. Today in Mexico, nichos and altars to saints, (especially to the Virgin of Guadalupe, who is the patron saint of Mexico) are present in homes and in businesses, often dressed up with flower and candle offerings.

name: Wrestling masks
description:
MASKS AVAILABLE ONLY AT THE SHOP NOT ONLINE

Adult size, one fits all.

Masks are a very special part of the Mexican culture and recall early Hispanic times.
Mexican wrestling masks are great collectibles and awesome pieces of art.
Every Mexican Wrestling mask is handmade and depending on its quality and style, takes anywhere from 3 to 11 hours to be completed.

name: Handkerchiefs
description:
Made of cotton. Dimensions: 60cm by 60cm.

For more than three hundred years, the Virgin Mary of Guadalupe has been celebrated and revered in Mexico as the Patroness of Mexican and Indian peoples, and as the Queen of the Americas.
She stands on home altars, lends her name to men and women alike, and finds herself at rest under their skin in tattoos. Guadalupe‚Äôs image proliferates on candles, decals, tiles, murals, and old and new sacred art. Churches and religious orders carry her name, as do place names and streets. Far from vulgarizing her image, these items personalize her and maintain her presence in daily life.
